pectuscumpalati: <entryFree id="n34284" type="gloss" key="Pectuscum Pa^la_ti"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pectuscum Pălāti</orth>, <sense id="n34284.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a part of Rome</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pectuscum Palati dicta est ea regio Urbis, quam Romulus obversam posuit eā parte, in quā plurimum erat agri Romani ad mare versus, et qui (l. qua) mollissime adibatur Urbs, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=213" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 213</bibl></cit> Müll. [pectus, qs. <hi rend="ital">breastwork</hi>].</sense></entryFree>
pecu: <entryFree id="n34285" type="main" key="pe^cu"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcu</orth> (<case>dat.</case> pecui, Lucil. ap. Gell. infra; <number>plur.</number>: pecua, pecuda; <sense id="n34285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> pecuum, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:3:37" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 3, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecubus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1132</bibl></cit>), <gen>n.</gen> <etym>v. pecus</etym>, <hi rend="ital">cattle</hi>, esp. the larger kinds (mostly ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">pastor harum dormit, quom eunt sic a pecu palitantes,</quote> <trans><tr>the flock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne balant quidem, quom a pecu cetero apsunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2, 20</bibl></cit>: luna muribus fibras Et pecui addit, Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 8, 4</bibl>.—In <number>plur.</number>: pastores pecuaque salva servassis, an old formula of prayer in <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 141, 3</bibl>: homines, pecua beluasque, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 6</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:ib. 9" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> ib. 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:21:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 21, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(asinus) non generatur in Ponto, nec aequinoctio verno, ut cetera pecua admittitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 43, 68, § 167</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecua ruri pascere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 3, 1, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34285.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34285.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: pecua, <hi rend="ital">the places where cattle are kept</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pastures</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum hostium copiae non longe absunt, pecua relinquuntur, agri cultura deseritur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 6, 15</bibl></cit> Halm ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Italia contremuit, statim pecua agrique deserta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Or. 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34285.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Money</hi> (cf. pecunia): <cit><quote lang="la">pecua in cruminā defero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:5:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 5, 64</bibl></cit>: pecuum, Cato ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=246" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 246</bibl> Müll.: greges pecuum, Host. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 719</bibl> P.—</sense><sense id="n34285.4" n="C" level="2"> Pecu squamosum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">fish</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 3, 5</bibl> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1132</bibl>, the correct read. is pigris balantibus; v. Lachm. ad h. l.).</sense></entryFree>
pecualis: <entryFree id="n34286" type="main" key="pe^cu^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecu</etym>, <sense id="n34286.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to cattle</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">animal pecuale,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sedul.</author> 1, 146</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuarius: <entryFree id="n34287" type="main" key="pe^cu^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34287.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to cattle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">res pecuaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuarii greges,</quote> <trans><tr>herds of cattle</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaestio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotiatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:1:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">canis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:12:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 12, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <trans><tr>a stock of cattle</tr>, <tr>live stock</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 3, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34287.1" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n34287.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n34287.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A cattle-breeder</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grazier</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">diligentissimus agricola et pecuarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:9:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34287.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A farmer of the public pastures</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">damnatis aliquot pecuariis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:47:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 47, 4</bibl></cit>; Inscr. Don. cl. 9, n. 13.—</sense><sense id="n34287.5" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a stock of cattle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis pecuariae pecus fundamentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse pecuarias habui grandes, in Apuliā oviarias, in Reatino equarias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2</bibl></cit>, praef. § 6; 2, 1, 3.—Also, <hi rend="ital">cattle-breeding</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">librum de pecuariā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>— </sense><sense id="n34287.6" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭārĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">herds of cattle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mitte in Venerem pecuaria primus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:3:9" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 9, 9, § 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuasco: <entryFree id="n34288" type="spur" key="pe^cu^asco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭasco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, a false read. for pecus pascere, Minuc. Sentent. de Fin<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:Genuat. 1:32, p. 6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Genuat. 1, 32, p. 6</bibl> Rudorff.</entryFree>
pecuatus: <entryFree id="n34289" type="main" key="pe^cu^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecu</etym>, <sense id="n34289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">beastly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brutal</hi>, Fulg. Moral. n. 35; cf. pecuatus, <foreign lang="greek">qhriw/dhs</foreign>, Onomast. Vet.</sense></entryFree>
pecuda: <entryFree id="n34290" type="main" key="pe^cu^da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭda</orth>, v. pecu and 2. pecus.</entryFree>
pecudalis: <entryFree id="n34291" type="main" key="pe^cu^da_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭdālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecu</etym>, <sense id="n34291.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to cattle</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 8, § 806</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecudifer: <entryFree id="n34292" type="gloss" key="Pe^cu^di^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pĕcŭdĭfer</orth>, <itype>fĕra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecufero,<pb n="1322" /> <cb n="PECU" />  cattle-bearing</etym>, <sense id="n34292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of Sylvanus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Murat.</author> 70, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuinus: <entryFree id="n34293" type="main" key="pe^cu^i_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcŭīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecu</etym>. <sense id="n34293.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">of cattle</hi> (ante- and post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">daps,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 132, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ossa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 215, 49</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuina et ferina,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n34293.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">beastly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brutal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. 281, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
peculator: <entryFree id="n34294" type="main" key="pe^cu_la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>peculor</etym>, <sense id="n34294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an embezzler of public money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a peculator</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:18:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 18, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:3:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 3, 2</bibl>; Salv. Gub. Dei, 7, 21.</sense></entryFree>
peculatorius: <entryFree id="n34295" type="spur" key="pe^cu_la_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, a corrupt read., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=95" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 95</bibl>; v. Müll. ad loc.</entryFree>
peculatus: <entryFree id="n34296" type="main" key="pe^cu_la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlātus</orth> (PEQVLATVS, Lex Apparit., <sense id="n34296.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">in the foll.</ref></xr>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>peculor</etym>. </sense><sense id="n34296.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an embezzlement of public money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peculation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculatus furtum publicum a pecore dictum, sicut et pecunia, eo quod antiqui Romani nihil praeter pecora habebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=212" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 212</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">perfidia et peculatus ex urbe si exulant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 5, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculatum facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accusari peculatus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 1, 12, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculatus damnari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 18, 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">SINE MALO PEQVLATV, Lex Apparit. Grut. 628: judices qui peculatu provincias quassavissent, Cod. Th. 9, 28, 1: ad legem Juliam peculatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48</bibl></cit>, tit. 13.—</sense><sense id="n34296.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of the caprice of love: perfidiosus est Amor. <hi rend="ital">Si.</hi> Ergo in me peculatum facit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 73</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
peculiaris: <entryFree id="n34297" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^a_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>peculium</etym>, <sense id="n34297.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to private property.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34297.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculiaris causa,</quote> <trans><tr>concerning property</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:2:44" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 2, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculiari nomine,</quote> <trans><tr>on account of property</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:14:12:16" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 14, 12, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34297.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34297.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One's own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to one</hi> (cf. proprius): <cit><quote lang="la">etiam opilio, qui pascit alienas oves, aliquam habet peculiarem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovem tibi dabo peculiarem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 3, 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut peculiare aliquid in fundo pascere liceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15:1:22" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 15, 1, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23" default="NO">23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:1:31" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 12, 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:33:6:9" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 33, 6, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vectigalibus peculiares servos praeposuit,</quote> <trans><tr>belonging to him</tr>, <tr>his own</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:76" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 76</bibl></cit>: prolatos manu sua e peculiaribus loculis suis <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34297.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One's own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">belonging particularly to one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not held in common with others; proper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">special</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peculiar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">venio ad Lysaniam, peculiarem tuum, Deciane, testem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 21, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc mihi peculiare fuerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">edictum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:14:section=36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 14, § 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:19:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 19, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi proprio suo et peculiari deo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:5" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Africae peculiare, quod in oleastro inserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 18, 30, § 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec sunt peculiaria Arabiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 17, 38, § 77</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:140" default="NO" valid="yes">19, 8, 41, § 140</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">me peculiaris quidem impedit ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:8:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 8, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">luce peculiari nitere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:64:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 64, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sis ei populus peculiaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:26:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 26, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in populum peculiarem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34297.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Singular</hi>, <hi rend="ital">particular</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extraordinary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peculiar</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">peculiari merito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peculiare munus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:36:4:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 36, 4, 3</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭārĭ-ter</orth>. </sense><sense id="n34297.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">As private property</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam etiam ignorantes possidemus, id est quae servi peculiariter paraverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:2:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 2, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:20:6:8" default="NO">20, 6, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34297.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Especially</hi>, <hi rend="ital">particularly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peculiarly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">folia peculiariter cruribus vitiosis utilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 8, 33, § 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicinae peculiariter curiosus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 2, 3, § 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:130" default="NO">11, 3, 130</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:2:8" default="NO">8, 2, 8</bibl> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 20, 37, § 145</bibl>, the correct read. is peculiaris, not peculiarius; v Sillig ad h. l.).</sense></entryFree>
peculiarius: <entryFree id="n34298" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34298.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to private property</hi> (post-class. for the class. peculiaris): <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:44:4:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 44, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15:1:4" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 15, 1, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> (al. peculiari); <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Murat.</author> 1640, 7</bibl>: peculium peculiarius, Not. Tir.</sense></entryFree>
peculiatus: <entryFree id="n34299" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from peculio.</entryFree>
peculio: <entryFree id="n34300" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>peculium</etym>, <sense id="n34300.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to give</hi> one something <hi rend="ital">for one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as one's private property;</hi> hence, comic. in mal. part., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 2, 2, 10</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕ-cūlĭātus</orth>. <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">furnished with property of his own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that has private property.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34300.1" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">servus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:18" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 21, 1, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:1:13" default="NO">19, 1, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34300.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34300.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Furnished</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provided</hi> with money: bene peculiatus, Asin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:32:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 32, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertus satis peculiatus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34300.4" n="2" level="3"> In mal. part.: <cit><quote lang="la">pulchre pensilibus peculiati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Priap.</author> 53</bibl></cit>. <cb n="PECU" /></sense></entryFree>
peculiolum: <entryFree id="n34301" type="gloss" key="pe^cu_li^o^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭŏlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>peculium</etym>, <sense id="n34301.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little private property</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:46" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 46</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
peculiosus: <entryFree id="n34302" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34302.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">having a large private property</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wealthy</hi> (ante- and post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">servus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 1, 2, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 2, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Psa. 38" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Psa. 38</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
peculium: <entryFree id="n34303" type="main" key="pe^cu_li^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>pecus</etym>, lit., <sense id="n34303.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">property in cattle;</hi> hence, as in early times all property consisted of cattle, in gen., <hi rend="ital">property.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34303.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34303.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">peculi sui prodigi (servi),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 4, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupiditas peculii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 5, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cura peculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 33</bibl></cit> Serv.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 330</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34303.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">private property.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34303.4" n="1" level="3"> What the master of the house saves and lays by, <hi rend="ital">money laid by</hi>, <hi rend="ital">savings</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:32:1:77" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 32, 1, 77</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34303.5" n="2" level="3"> What a wife owns as her independent property, and over which her husband has no control, <hi rend="ital">a private purse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">paraphernalia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:3:9:section=3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 23, 3, 9, § 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34303.6" n="3" level="3"> That which is given by a father or master to his son, daughter, or slave, as his or her <hi rend="ital">private property</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">frugi sum, nec potest peculium enumerari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:4:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 4, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adimere servis peculium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:1:17:5" default="NO">1, 17, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">filii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 41</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 11:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 11, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Juliam uxorem peculio concesso a patre praebitisque annuis, fraudavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:50" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cultis augere peculia servis,</quote> <trans><tr>fees</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:189" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 189</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34303.7" n="4" level="3"> Castrense, <hi rend="ital">the private property of a son acquired by military service</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with the consent of his father</hi> (profecticium), or <hi rend="ital">by inheritance through his mother</hi> (adventicium); <hi rend="ital">then called</hi> quasi castrense, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:17:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 49, 17, 5</bibl> sqq.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 3, 4</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:6:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 37, 6, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34303.8" n="5" level="3"> = membrum virile, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 92</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0972,001:8" default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> S. 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Elag. 9</bibl>; cf. peculiatus.—</sense><sense id="n34303.9" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that which belongs to one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one's own.</hi>—Of a letter: <cit><quote lang="la">sine ullo ad me peculio veniet?</quote> <trans><tr>without any thing for myself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 12:9" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 12, 9</bibl></cit>.—Of the people of lsrael: <cit><quote lang="la">erunt mihi, in die quā ego facio, in peculium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,047:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Mal. 3, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
peculor: <entryFree id="n34304" type="main" key="pe^cu_lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <sense id="n34304.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep. n.</hi> [peculium], <hi rend="ital">to defraud the public</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to embezzle the public money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to peculate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem publicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:17:3" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 17, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>—As <hi rend="ital">subst. plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūlantĭa</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">peculations</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Commod.</author> 70, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pecunia: <entryFree id="n34305" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (on the oldest inscrr., also written PEQVNIA, as PEQVDES, PEQVLIVM), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>pecus, because the wealth of the ancients consisted in cattle: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus, a quo pecunia universa, quod in pecore pecunia tum consistebat pastoribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=95" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 95</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf. Fest. s. v. peculatus, p. 212 and 213 Müll.</etym>, <sense id="n34305.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">property</hi>, <hi rend="ital">riches</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wealth</hi> (cf.: divitiae, res, bona, etc.). </sense><sense id="n34305.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia sacrificium fieri dicebatur, cum frugum fructuumque causā mola pura offerebatur in sacrificio, quia omnis res familiaris, quam nunc pecuniam dicimus, ex his rebus constaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=244" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 244</bibl></cit> and 245 Müll.: SI FVRIOSVS EST AGNATORVM GENTILIVMQVE IN EO PECVNIAQVE EIVS POTESTAS ESTO, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:50:148" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 50, 148</bibl>; ib. ap. Ulp. Fragm. tit. 11, § 14: QVI CORONAM PARIT IPSE PECVNIAVE EIVS VIRTVTIS ERGO DVITOR EI, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 3, 5, § 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniam facere,</quote> <trans><tr>to accumulate property</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:49:111" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 49, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in alienam pecuniam invadere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut pecunia fortunisque nostris contentus sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">familiae aliquot cum mapalibus pecoribusque suis (ea pecunia illis est), etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34305.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">money</hi> (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">argentum, nummus): qui dabant olim pecuniam, non adnumerabant eam, sed appendebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 1:122" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 1, 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praesenti pecuniā mercari aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia vaenibunt praesenti pecuniā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:9:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 9, 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia numerata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:13:53" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 13, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia publica ex aerario erogata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:71:section=165" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 71, § 165</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">certa,</quote> <trans><tr>a specified sum</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 5, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potestas pecuniae conficiendae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:13:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 13, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">permagnam ex illā re pecuniam confici posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:52:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 52, 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniam cogere a civitatibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 73</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">171: pecuniam numerare alicui ab aerario,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">177: pecuniam publicam domum suam convertere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">176: pecunias civitatibus distribuere ... avertere atque auferre,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 73</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">171: devorare pecuniam publicam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">177: pecuniam alicui dissolvere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 77</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">180: solvere alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 21, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunias conferre ad statuas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:77:section=180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 77, § 180</bibl></cit>: alicui conferre in usum ejus, id. <cb n="PECU" /> Fl. 23, 55: <cit><quote lang="la">transferre in quaestum et fenerationem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 23, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deferre alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 23, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">credita nobis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gravi fenore occupare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 25, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">collocatam habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 7, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex aerario exhaurire, ex vectigalibus redigere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:36:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 36, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exige pecuniam a civitatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:87:section=202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 87, § 202</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab sociis maximam pecuniam auferre,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 96</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">224: plura mala nobis exhibet quam aliud quidquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Tranq. 8:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Tranq. 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">majore tormento possidetur quam quaeritur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 19:6:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 19, 6, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et pecuniae obediunt omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,030:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccl. 10, 19</bibl></cit>.—So in <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunias exigere, capere, imperare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:16:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 16, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunias auferre ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:76:section=175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 76, § 175</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunias sumere mutuas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 10</bibl></cit>, § 28; <cit><quote lang="la">2, 2, 70, § 170: mutuas pecunias faenore quaerens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:49:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 49, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 9</bibl>; cf. Zumpt ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1, p. 70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, p. 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">DIES PECVNIAE,</quote> <trans><tr>the day of payment</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 207, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n34305.3" n="2" level="3"> (Late Lat.) <hi rend="ital">Copper coins</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scenicis numquam aurum, numquam argentum, vix pecuniam donavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 33, § 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34305.4" n="3" level="3"> Personified: <cit><quote lang="la">Pecunia,</quote> <trans><tr>the goddess of gain</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, 132</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:113" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 113</bibl>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">an epithet of Jupiter</hi>, Aug. Civ. Dei, 7, 11; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:ib. 4:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 21</bibl>; cf. also <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecunialis: <entryFree id="n34306" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecunia</etym>, <sense id="n34306.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniary</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">quaestus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 1:5:147" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 1, 5, 147</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuniarie: <entryFree id="n34307" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^a_ri^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭārĭē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. pecuniarius <sense id="n34307.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
pecuniaris: <entryFree id="n34308" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^a_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pecunia</etym>, <sense id="n34308.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniary</hi> (post-class. and rare for pecuniarius): <cit><quote lang="la">damnatio,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to pay a fine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> dub. (al. pecuniaria).—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭārĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">relating to money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniarily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:1:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 47, 1, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuniarius: <entryFree id="n34309" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34309.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniary</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">rei pecuniariae socius,</quote> <trans><tr>in a money matter</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:40:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 40, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praemia rei pecuniariae magna,</quote> <trans><tr>great rewards in money</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ep. ad Brut. 1, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:50" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaestiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:1:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 3, 1, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condemnatio,</quote> <trans><tr>to pay a fine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:42:1:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 42, 1, 6</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n34309.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭārĭus</orth>, <foreign lang="greek">xrhmatisth/s</foreign>, Gloss. Gr. Lat.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭārĭē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">pecuniarily</hi>: i. q. pecuniariter. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:2:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 16, 2, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuniola: <entryFree id="n34310" type="main" key="Pe^cu_ni^o^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pĕcūnĭŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34310.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the surname of one P. Aurelius in the first Punic war</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:7:4" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 7, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pecuniosus: <entryFree id="n34311" type="main" key="pe^cu_ni^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcūnĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34311.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has much money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moneyed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wealthy.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34311.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">tum erat res in pecore et locorum possessionibus, ex quo pecuniosi et locupletes vocabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:9:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 9, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines copiis rei familiaris locupletes et pecuniosi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:15:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 15, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feminae pecuniosiores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo pecuniosissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:9:section=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 9, § 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 16, 47</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n34311.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that brings money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gain ful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">artes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:56:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 56, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pecus: <entryFree id="n34312" type="main" key="pe^cus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcus</orth>, <itype>pecŏris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>Zend, pacu, cattle; cf. Goth. faihu; Angl.-Sax. feó, cattle; Germ. Vieh; Engl. fee. Fick refers the word to root pag- of pango, etc.</etym>, <sense id="n34312.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cattle</hi>, as a collective, <hi rend="ital">a herd</hi> (opp.: pecus, pecudis, a single head of cattle). </sense><sense id="n34312.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34312.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">bubulum pecus,</quote> <trans><tr>horned cattle</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:13:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 13, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovile,</quote> <trans><tr>sheep</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1</bibl></cit> prooem.: <cit><quote lang="la">caprile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus majus et minus ... de pecore majore, in quo sunt ad tres species naturā discreti, boves, asini, equi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:12" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equinum,</quote> <trans><tr>a stud</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 72</bibl></cit>: setigerum pecus, <hi rend="ital">the bristly herd</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the herd of swine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:288" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 288</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammatum pecus,</quote> <trans><tr>the thirsty steeds</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:733" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 733</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volatile pecus,</quote> <trans><tr>fowls</tr>, <tr>hens</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavum fucos pecus a praesepibus arcent,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the drones</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 168</bibl></cit>.—So of bees, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:8:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 8, 6</bibl>.—Of seals: <cit><quote lang="la">omne cum Proteus pecus egit altos Visere montes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">of fish: aquatile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:17:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 17, 7</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n34312.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic, of sheep, <hi rend="ital">small cattle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a flock</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecori et bubus diligenter substernatur. Scabiem pecori et jumentis caveto (shortly after: frondem substernito ovibus bubusque),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 5, 7</bibl></cit>: boni pastoris est pecus tondere non deglubere, Tiber. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:32" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">balatus pecorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:554" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 554</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 47, 72, § 187</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34312.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34312.5" n="A" level="2"> Of a single animal: <cit><quote lang="la">inque pecus magnae subito vertare parentis = pecudem,</quote> <trans><tr>the young lion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:459" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 459</bibl></cit>; Mos. et Rom. Leg. Coll. 6, 7, 9.—In late and eccl. lat. the distinction<pb n="1323" /> <cb n="PEDA" />  between <itype>pecus</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, and <itype>pecus</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, nearly disappears, and the latter is found in all senses of the words; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:20:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 20, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:14:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2 Par. 14, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:66:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Isa. 66, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34312.6" n="B" level="2"> Contemptuously, or as a term of abuse, of persons, <hi rend="ital">cattle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mutum et turpe pecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o imitatores, servum pecus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 19, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simul ite, Dindymenae dominae vaga pecora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed venale pecus Corythae posteritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:62" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 62</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n34313" type="main" key="pe^cus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcus</orth>, <itype>ŭdis</itype> (<sense id="n34313.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>: pecudi marito, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 659</bibl> P. or Trag. v. 336 Vahl.—<hi rend="ital">Nom. sing.</hi>, Caesar ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 719</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 72</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi> collat. form, <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi>, pecuda, Att., Sisenn., and Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 11</bibl>; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>same root with pecu and pecus, ŏris</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a single head of cattle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a beast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">animal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of a herd</hi> (opp.: pecus, pecŏris, cattle collectively; different from animal, which includes man). </sense><sense id="n34313.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34313.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">Neptuni pecudes terrestres pecudes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">squammigerum pecudes,</quote> <trans><tr>the fishes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:343" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 343</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus aequoreum, pecudes pictaeque volucres,</quote> <trans><tr>land animals</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 243</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genera pecudum ferarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: anates buxeis rostris pecudes, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 460, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā pecude (sc. sue) nihil genuit natura fecundius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:64:160" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 64, 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantum natura hominis pecudibus reliquisque bestiis antecedat,</quote> <trans><tr>domestic animals</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:30:105" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 30, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ista non modo homines, sed ne pecudes quidem mihi passurae esse videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 9, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 16, 6</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur. neutr.</hi> pecuda: vagant, pavore pecuda in tumulis deserunt, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 11</bibl>; Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 17</bibl>: cum adhibent in pecuda pastores, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34313.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n34313.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A head of small cattle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of a flock</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">at variae crescunt pecudes armenta feraeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:228" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 228</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34313.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A sheep</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haedi cornigeras norunt matres, agnique petulci balantum pecudes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:369" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 369</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:903" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 903</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecudem spondere sacello Balantem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:232" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus et caprae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 11, 53, § 90</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34313.6" n="3" level="3"> Collectively, = 1. pecus, id genus pecudis, <hi rend="ital">horses</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:27:13" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 27, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34313.7" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, as a term of reproach for an ignorant, stupid, or filthy person, <hi rend="ital">a beast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brute</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">istius, pecudis ac putidae carnis consilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:9:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 9, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">istius impurissimae atque intemperantissimae pecudis sordes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 29, 72</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:8:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 8, 3, 9</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Gaius Caesar pecudem auream eum appellare solitus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n34314" type="main" key="pe^cus3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, i. q. 1. pecus, Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 8, 4</bibl>.</entryFree>
pecusculum: <entryFree id="n34315" type="hapax" key="pe^cuscu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕcuscŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>1. pecus</etym>, <sense id="n34315.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an animalcule</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Juvenc.</author> 2, 593</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
peda: <entryFree id="n34316" type="gloss" key="pe^da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n34316.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a footstep</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">peda vestigium humani praecipue pedis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=210" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 210</bibl></cit> Müll.: peda, pedatura, <foreign lang="greek">i)/xnos</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
pedalion: <entryFree id="n34317" type="main" key="pe^da_li^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdālĭon</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n34317.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">called also</hi> proserpinaca, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedalis: <entryFree id="n34318" type="main" key="pe^da_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pes</etym>, <sense id="n34318.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foot-.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34318.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.; hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. solea), <hi rend="ital">a slipper</hi>, Petr 56.—</sense><sense id="n34318.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">of the size of a foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of a foot</hi>, as a measure; <hi rend="ital">a foot in length</hi>, <hi rend="ital">breadth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thickness</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">sol mihi videtur quasi pedalis,</quote> <trans><tr>a foot in diameter</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 26, 82</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 1:3:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 1, 3, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">transtra ex pedalibus in latitudinem trabibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">longitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:7:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crassitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 8, 4, § 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">altitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:247" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 22, 91, § 247</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:16:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 16, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intervalla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 4, 10, § 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sulcus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 17, 20, 33, § 146</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a measure;</hi> in gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">tuae praecisionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:51:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 51, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pedamen: <entryFree id="n34319" type="main" key="pe^da_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdāmen</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>1. pedo</etym>, <sense id="n34319.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a stake</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prop</hi>, with which trees and vines are supported: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus stat recta vinea, dicuntur pedamenta: quae transversa junguntur, juga ... Pedamentum fere quattuor generum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:8:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 8, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:1:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:26:1" default="NO">4, 26, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:30:1" default="NO">4, 30, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedaminibus annexae vites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:4:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 4, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 20, 34, § 147</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedaneus: <entryFree id="n34320" type="main" key="pe^da_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdānĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pes</etym>, <sense id="n34320.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of the size of a foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a foot in length</hi>, <hi rend="ital">breadth</hi>, etc. </sense><sense id="n34320.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">pedaneum super rudus inducimus,</quote> <trans><tr>a foot thick</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 6, 11, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedanei ramuli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 2, 42</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34320.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n34320.3" n="A" level="2"> Pedanei judices, <hi rend="ital">petty judges</hi> that tried only trifling cases (so called because they had only a low seat and no tribunal), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:1:1:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 3, 1, 1, § 6</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:7:3" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:38:section=10" default="NO">48, 19, 38, § 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 28</bibl>; cf. Ps.-Ascon. ad Cic. Div. in <cb n="PEDE" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0013,001:15" default="NO"><author>Caecil.</author> 15</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34320.4" n="B" level="2"> Pedanei senatores, for pedarii senatores, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:18:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 18, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedanus: <entryFree id="n34321" type="main" key="Pe^da_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pĕdānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. 2. Pedum, II.</entryFree>
pedarius: <entryFree id="n34322" type="main" key="pe^da_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pes</etym>, <sense id="n34322.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foot-.</hi>—Only transf. </sense><sense id="n34322.1" n="I" level="1"> pedarii senatores, <hi rend="ital">those senators who had not yet been entered by the censors on the list or roll of senators</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and who had no vote of their own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but could merely signify their assent to that of another</hi>, Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:18:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 18, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 65</bibl>.—Also as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdārii</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:19:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 19, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 20, 4</bibl>; and in <number>sing.</number>: pedarī sententia, Laber. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:18:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 18, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34322.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of the size of a foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a foot long</hi>, <hi rend="ital">broad</hi>, etc.: EX TIGNO PEDARIO, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a foot wide</hi>, Lex. Puteol. ap. Grut. 207, 2.</sense></entryFree>
pedasa: <entryFree id="n34323" type="main" key="Pe_da^sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pēdăsa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pēdăsum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ph/dasa</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*ph/dason</foreign>, <sense id="n34323.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Caria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:30:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 30, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedatim: <entryFree id="n34324" type="hapax" key="pe^da_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>pes</etym>, <sense id="n34324.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">foot by foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one foot after another</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">leo tantum et camelus (gradiuntur) pedatim, hoc est, ut sinister pes non transeat dextrum sed subsequatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 45, 105, § 253</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pedatura: <entryFree id="n34325" type="main" key="pe^da_tu_ra1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n34325.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the space</hi> or <hi rend="ital">extent of a foot</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 896, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Don.</author> 168, 1</bibl>; ib. cl. 13, n. 29.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n34326" type="main" key="pe^da_tu_ra2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. pedo</etym>, <sense id="n34326.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a prop</hi> of a vine: <cit><quote lang="la">VINEAE,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 215, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pedatus: <entryFree id="n34327" type="main" key="pe^da_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. 1. pedo, I.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n34328" type="main" key="pe^da_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype> (collat. form of the <sense id="n34328.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi> pĕdāto, Cato; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">in the foll.</ref></xr>), <gen>m.</gen> <etym>1. pedo</etym>, <hi rend="ital">an attack</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a charge</hi> against an enemy (ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">nisi pedatu tertio omnes afflixero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 2, 1, 50</bibl></cit>; for which: igitur tertio pedato nobis bellum fecere, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 64, 20</bibl>; cf.: tertio pedatu, <foreign lang="greek">tri/th| perio/dw|</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.; and: <cit><quote lang="la">pedato positum pro repetitu vel accessu quasi per pedem, sicuti nunc vulgo dicitur tertio pedato,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 64, 16 sq.</bibl></cit>; Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 64, 20</bibl>; id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 191</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedeplana: <entryFree id="n34329" type="main" key="pe^de^pla_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdĕplāna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. loca) [pesplanus], <sense id="n34329.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">rooms on the ground-floor</hi> (postclass.), Cod. Th. 7, 8, 13.</sense></entryFree>
pedepressim: <entryFree id="n34330" type="gloss" key="pe^de_^pressim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdē^pressim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>pes-premo</etym>, <sense id="n34330.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cautiously</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedetentim et pedepressim dictum est caute, quasi lenta et tarda itione,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 29, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pedes: <entryFree id="n34331" type="main" key="pe^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdes</orth>, <itype>itis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>pes</etym>, <sense id="n34331.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that is</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goes on foot.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34331.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam si pedes incedat,</quote> <trans><tr>on foot</tr>, <tr>afoot</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 9, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum pedes iret in hostem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:881" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 881</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">silvā pedes errat in altā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:364" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 364</bibl></cit>.—Esp., apposit.: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam si pedes incedat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 9, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Macedones sciverunt ne (Alexander) pedes venaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:1:18" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse equo desiluit, pedesque per nives ingredi coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:6:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmen circumibat pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:3:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 3, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34331.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n34331.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A foot-soldier</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">postulavit ne quem peditem ad colloquium Caesar adduceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 42</bibl></cit>: equitum et peditum copiae, <hi rend="ital">foot-soldiers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foot</hi>, Pomp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 12</bibl>, C, 1: <cit><quote lang="la">tria milia et septingenti pedites ierunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:40:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 40, 5</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n34331.4" n="2" level="3"> Collect., in <number>sing.</number>, <hi rend="ital">foot-soldiers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">infantry.</hi> cum pedes concurrit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in pedite robur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simul pedes, eques, classis apud praedictum amnem convenere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 70</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34331.5" n="3" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: equites pedites, as a general designation for <hi rend="ital">the</hi> entire <hi rend="ital">people;</hi> cf. colloq. Engl. <hi rend="ital">horse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and dragoons</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equitum peditumque prolem describunto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:3:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes cives Romani equites peditesque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romani tollent equites peditesque cachinnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 113</bibl></cit>.— In <number>sing.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">quodvis genus hominum ibi videas, equitem, peditem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34331.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A land-soldier</hi> (opp. to a marine, classicus): <cit><quote lang="la">classicae peditumque expeditiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:121:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 121, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pedester: <entryFree id="n34332" type="main" key="pe^dester"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdester</orth>, <itype>tris, tre</itype> (<sense id="n34332.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">masc.</hi> pedestris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Prob. 21, 1</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <hi rend="ital">on foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that goes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is done</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">on foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pedestrian.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34332.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">gratior illi videtur statua pedestris futura, quam equestris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equestres et pedestres copiae,</quote> <trans><tr>foot-soldiers</tr>, <tr>infantry</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:34:112" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 34, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">copiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:17 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 17 al.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">pedester exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestre scutum,</quote> <trans><tr>of a foot-soldier</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proelium duplex equestre ac pedestre commisit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestris acies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34332.2" n="2" level="3"> In <hi rend="ital">plur. subst.</hi> pedestres, <hi rend="ital">foot-soldiers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 9</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">people on foot</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:14:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 14, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:6:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Marc. 6, 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n34332.3" n="3" level="3"> Pedestria auspicia nominabantur,<cb n="PEDI" />  quae dabantur a vulpe, lupo, equo, ceterisque animalibus quadrupedibus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=244" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 244</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n34332.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">on land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by land</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestres navalesque pugnae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestria itinera,</quote> <trans><tr>the roads by land</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">proelia pedestria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:4:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 4, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">transitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 101</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Spect. 28" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Spect. 28</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n34332.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of style, like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pezo/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">not rising above the ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not elevated.</hi> </sense><sense id="n34332.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Written in prose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prose</hi> (Gr. idiom; <cit><quote lang="la">Lat. prosa oratio): Plato multum supra prosam orationem et quam pedestrem Graeci vocant, surgit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:81" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestres historiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:12:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 12, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n34332.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Plain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">common</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without poetic flights</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without pathos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prosaic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolet sermone pedestri Telephus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid prius inlustrem satiris musāque pedestri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 6, 17</bibl></cit> (for which: <cit><quote lang="la">sermones Repentes per humum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 251</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">opus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 16, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:page=2433" default="NO"><author>Ter. Maur.</author> p. 2433</bibl></cit> P.</sense></entryFree>
pedetemptim: <entryFree id="n34333" type="main" key="pe^de^temptim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdĕtemptim</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕdĕtentim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>pes-tendo; qs. by stretching out the feet; cf. Doed. Syn. 3, p. 98; hence</etym>, <sense id="n34333.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">step by step</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slowly</hi> (syn.: paulatim, sensim). </sense><sense id="n34333.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: expectando excrucior. <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Pedetemptim, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 32</bibl>: pedetemptim et sedato nisu, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:21:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 21, 48</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 91 Rib.).—Of elephants: <cit><quote lang="la">quaerendis pedetentim vadis, in terram evasere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 28 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n34333.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">by degrees</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gradually</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cautiously</hi> (class.): sensim et pedetemptim, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 29, 7</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:33:120" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 33, 120</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedetemptim et gradatim accessus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 14, 7</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">paulatim et ut dicitur pedetentim interrogando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:7:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 7, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timide et pedetemptim istuc descendunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 16</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">caute pedetemptimque omnia dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 42</bibl></cit>: viam tentare, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 190</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">di bene vortant quod agas! pedetemptim tamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 19</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: pedetemptius tibi consulam, M. Aur. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Ep. ad M. Caes. 3:2" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Ep. ad M. Caes. 3, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pedianus: <entryFree id="n34334" type="main" key="Pe^di^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pĕdĭānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. Asconius.</entryFree>
